deliberation: I examined the rhetorical questions and the phrase 'arm of YHWH'. The questions themselves are not figurative, but 'arm of YHWH' is a standard anthropomorphic expression in Hebrew for God’s power in action, functioning as both metaphor (God portrayed with a human arm) and metonymy/synecdoche (arm for strength). I treat this as one complex figurative instance.

instances.english_text: Upon whom has the arm of the LORD been revealed?
target: YHWH’s powerful saving action through the servant
vehicle: strong human arm as body part
posture: speaker laments that this power is hidden from most
instances.explanation: God’s effective power to save is pictured as an ‘arm’ being revealed, using human anatomy (arm) as a metaphor and metonymy for divine strength in action.

deliberation: I checked the growth imagery and the description of his lack of beauty. The two clauses introduced by כ־ are explicit similes comparing the servant’s emergence to a young plant and to a root in dry ground. The later statements about ‘no form or majesty’ can be taken literally about social/physical unattractiveness and are not clearly figurative in themselves.

instances.english_text: He grew up like a sapling before Him
target: the servant’s early growth and appearance
instances.explanation: The servant’s development is likened to a tender shoot, highlighting his fragility and apparent insignificance through plant imagery.

instances.english_text: and like a root out of arid ground
target: his emergence from an unfavorable context
history of God’s people in hardship
ground: life emerging despite harsh, life-denying conditions
posture: speaker underscores how unlikely his flourishing appears
tone of surprise at such emergence
instances.explanation: His rise is compared to a root trying to grow from dry soil, stressing how unlikely and unpromising his context is.

deliberation: I evaluated whether ‘man of pains’ is figurative; it is mainly a genitive of characteristic. The key figurative element is introduced by כ־: ‘like a hiding of faces from him’ / ‘as one from whom people hide their faces’. This is a simile picturing social rejection by the culturally meaningful gesture of turning away the face.

instances.english_text: As one from whom we hide our faces, he was despised
target: the community’s treatment of the servant
vehicle: a person people hide their faces from
social outcast from whom one averts the gaze
posture: speaker laments the depth of rejection
instances.explanation: The servant’s rejection is likened to the way people turn their faces away from someone shameful or repulsive, using the gesture of hiding one’s face as a vivid image of social shunning.

deliberation: I considered whether ‘plagued, smitten by God’ is figurative; it fits the ancient view of physical affliction as divine punishment and can be literal in their misperception. The clearest figurative language is the pair of verbs ‘he bore our sicknesses’ and ‘our pains he carried’, which conceptualize human afflictions as a heavy load he is shouldering.

instances.hebrew_text: אָכֵ֤ן חֳלָיֵ֙נוּ֙ ה֣וּא נָשָׂ֔א וּמַכְאֹבֵ֖ינוּ סְבָלָ֑ם
instances.english_text: Yet it was our sickness that he was bearing, our suffering that he endured (carried).
target: the servant’s vicarious taking on of the people’s afflictions
vehicle: a person loaded with a heavy burden
ground: taking weight off others onto oneself
enduring what properly belongs to others
posture: speaker reinterprets his suffering as purposeful burden-bearing
instances.explanation: The people’s sicknesses and pains are pictured as a heavy load that the servant ‘bears’ and ‘carries’, using burden-carrying as a metaphor for taking on others’ afflictions.

deliberation: I weighed whether ‘wounded’ and ‘crushed’ are literal or figurative; within the passion imagery they can denote real physical suffering. The clearest figurative element is the healing language: their moral/communal restoration through his stripes. ‘By his bruises we were healed’ uses bodily healing as a metaphor for being made whole from sins/iniquities.

instances.english_text: And by his bruises we were healed.
target: the community’s restoration from sin and estrangement
vehicle: healing from bodily wounds and disease
ground: removal of a harmful condition and restoration to wholeness
posture: speaker interprets their salvation in therapeutic terms
instances.explanation: The effect of the servant’s sufferings is described in terms of ‘healing’, using physical healing as a metaphor for moral and communal restoration brought about by his wounds.

deliberation: I noted an explicit simile (‘like sheep we went astray’), a common biblical metaphor of ‘way’ for life-conduct, and a burden-transfer image when YHWH causes iniquity to ‘meet’ or fall on him. These are three distinct figurative expressions: a simile of sheep, a path/life metaphor, and a burden/impact metaphor for guilt put on the servant.

instances.english_text: We all went astray like sheep
target: the people’s moral and spiritual wandering
vehicle: sheep that stray from the flock
ground: lack of guidance, vulnerability, foolish wandering
proneness to drift without a shepherd
instances.explanation: Their collective disobedience is compared to sheep wandering off, highlighting their vulnerability and lack of direction.

instances.english_text: Each of us turned to his own way
target: each person’s chosen pattern of life
ground: life as a path one chooses and follows
direction, orientation, and destination of conduct
personal autonomy in choosing a route
posture: speaker stresses personal responsibility in going one’s own way
instances.explanation: Life-conduct is conceptualized as a ‘way’ or path; turning to ‘one’s own way’ metaphorically describes choosing a self-directed, disobedient course of life.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיהֹוָה֙ הִפְגִּ֣יעַ בּ֔וֹ אֵ֖ת עֲוֺ֥ן כֻּלָּֽנוּ
instances.english_text: And the LORD laid on him (caused to meet in him) the guilt of all of us.
target: the transfer of the people’s guilt to the servant
vehicle: something falling upon or striking a person
ground: the guilt is treated as a weight or impact placed on him
he becomes the point where it ‘hits’
posture: speaker reinterprets events as divinely orchestrated burden-transfer
instances.explanation: The people’s iniquity is depicted as something that ‘meets’ or falls upon the servant, using the image of an impact or load to portray the transfer of guilt.

deliberation: The narrative of his silence is literal, but two clauses explicitly introduced by כ־ compare him to sacrificial sheep: one led to slaughter and one silent before shearers. These are two distinct but related similes emphasizing submissive, unresisting silence.

instances.english_text: Like a sheep being led to slaughter
target: the servant’s submissive acceptance of suffering
his passive yielding to hostile treatment
vehicle: a sheep led to the slaughterhouse
ground: docility, lack of resistance, vulnerability to death
posture: speaker underscores the servant’s meekness under oppression
instances.explanation: His unresisting acceptance of maltreatment is compared to a sheep led to slaughter, highlighting his docility in the face of death.

instances.english_text: And like a ewe, dumb before those who shear her
target: the servant’s refusal to defend himself verbally
ground: silence and powerlessness while being handled
submissive acceptance of an unpleasant process
instances.explanation: His silence in suffering is likened to a ewe silently enduring shearing, reinforcing the picture of uncomplaining submission.

deliberation: I examined legal and death language. ‘Oppressive judgment’ and ‘taken away’ can be literal. The phrase ‘cut off from the land of the living’ is a conventional idiom and metaphor for dying: life is pictured as a territory (“land of the living”) and death as being cut off from it.

instances.english_text: For he was cut off from the land of the living
target: the servant’s death and removal from the realm of the living
vehicle: being cut off from a land or territory
excision from a country or domain
ground: loss of membership in the sphere where the living dwell
ending of participation in common life
posture: speaker solemnly characterizes his death as exclusion from life’s realm
instances.explanation: Death is depicted as being ‘cut off’ from the ‘land of the living’, using territorial and cutting imagery as an idiomatic metaphor for dying.

deliberation: I checked ‘his grave with the wicked’ and ‘with a rich man in his deaths’ for figurative use; they most naturally describe the social company with whom he shares burial, not a metaphor. ‘No violence’ and ‘no deceit in his mouth’ state literal innocence. I do not find a clear, necessary instance of figurative language in this verse.

‘Crush’ and ‘make sick’ may be literal descriptions of intense suffering. The phrase ‘make his life a guilt-offering’ is the key figurative expression: his very ‘soul/life’ is equated with a specific sacrificial category (אָשָׁם), using cultic offering as a metaphor for his self-giving, atoning death.

instances.english_text: If he makes himself (his life) an offering for guilt
ground: substitution, bearing guilt, restoring relationship with God
life given in place of the guilty
satisfaction of divine justice through offering
posture: speaker frames his death in cultic, sacrificial categories
instances.explanation: The servant’s life is described as a ‘guilt-offering’, employing sacrificial ritual as a metaphor (and established idiom) for his atoning self-surrender.

deliberation: Expressions like ‘travail of his soul’ and being ‘satisfied’ can be heightened but not clearly figurative. The explicit vicarious language ‘their iniquities he will bear’ reprises the burden-bearing metaphor: sins are treated as a load carried by the servant.

instances.english_text: It is their punishment/iniquities that he bears.
target: the burden of the many’s iniquities
ground: carrying what belongs to others at cost to oneself
sustained endurance of a weight not one’s own
posture: speaker interprets his suffering as ongoing burden-bearing for many
instances.explanation: The many’s iniquities are depicted as a burden that the servant ‘bears’, using load-bearing as an idiomatic sacrificial metaphor for taking on others’ guilt.

deliberation: I distinguished three figurative clusters: (1) military/spoil imagery for his reward, (2) ‘poured out his soul to death’ picturing life as a liquid emptied out, and (3) ‘he bore the sin of many’ repeating the burden-bearing metaphor. ‘Numbered with transgressors’ can be taken as literal status rather than necessarily figurative.

instances.english_text: I will give him the many as his portion, he shall receive the multitude as his spoil.
target: the servant’s exaltation and share in the redeemed
vehicle: victorious warrior dividing plunder after battle
sharing out spoil among the strong
ground: receiving a rich share after costly struggle
honor and possession granted as victory reward
posture: speaker (God) portrays his reward in martial terms
instances.explanation: His exaltation and share in the many are portrayed through battle imagery, as if he were a victorious warrior dividing spoil.

instances.english_text: For he exposed/poured out himself to death
vehicle: pouring out or making bare something (like liquid from a vessel)
ground: complete expenditure and depletion of life
posture: speaker highlights the voluntariness and totality of his self-giving
instances.explanation: His death is pictured as ‘pouring out’ his soul, using the image of emptying a vessel to convey total self-expenditure unto death.

instances.english_text: Whereas he bore the guilt of the many
target: the many’s sins and their penalty
vehicle: load on a bearer’s back or shoulders
ground: taking onto oneself what burdens others
posture: speaker again interprets his work in burden-bearing terms
instances.explanation: The ‘sin of many’ is treated as a burden that he ‘bore’, using the established idiom and metaphor of carrying guilt as a weight transferred to the servant.
